facts.text: One Buddappa, his wife, his two unmarried daughters and his adopted son Buddanna were members of a Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: One Buddappa, his wife, his two unmarried daughters and his adopted son Buddanna were members of a Hindu undivided family.
Buddappa died on July 9, 1952.

facts.text: Buddappa was assessed during his lifetime in the status of a manager of the Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of the business dealings of the family, Buddappa was assessed during his life-time in the status of a manager of the Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: For the assessment year 1951-52 the Additional Income-tax Officer, Raichur, assessed Buddanna in respect of the income of the previous year which ended on November 8, 1950 as a Hindu undivided family under the title Sri. Gowli Buddappa deceased represented by his legal successor Sri. Gowli Buddanna, Oil Mills Owner, Raichur.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1951-52 the Additional Income-tax Officer, Raichur, assessed Buddanna in respect of the income of the previous year which ended on November 8, 1950 as a Hindu undivided family under the title Sri. Gowli Buddappa  deceased  represented by his legal successor Sri. Gowli Buddanna, Oil Mills Owner, Raichur.

facts.text: The order of assessment was confirmed in appeal by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, subject to the variation that the assessment was made under the title Buddanna - a Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: The order of assessment was confirmed in appeal by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, subject to the variation that the assessment was made under the title Buddanna - a Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal confirmed the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal confirmed the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: The Tribunal referred questions of law to the High Court of Mysore under s. 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal then referred the following questions of law to the High Court of Mysore for opinion under s. 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act

facts.text: High Court answered affirmatively to all referred questions.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court recorded answers in the affirmative on all the questions.

facts.text: With certificate under s. 66A, Buddanna appealed to the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: With certificate granted by the High Court under s. 66-A of the Indian Income-tax Act, Buddanna has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, Buddanna contended that he could only be assessed as an individual and ITO precluded by proviso to s. 26(2).

anchor.surface_text: Before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner it was contended by Buddanna that he could in law have only been assessed as an individual and that the Income-tax Officer was precluded by virtue of the proviso to s. 26(2) to pass the order for assessment for the year 1951-52 against him.

facts.text: AAC and Tribunal rejected Buddanna's contention.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Appellate Tribunal rejected that contention.

facts.text: Buddappa carried on business at Raichur which before January 26, 1950, formed part of the territory of H.E.H. the Nizam.

anchor.surface_text: Buddappa was a resident of and carried on business at Raichur which before January 26, 1950, formed part of the territory of H.E.H. the Nizam.

facts.text: The joint family of Buddappa and Buddanna was governed by the Mitakshara School of Hindu law.

anchor.surface_text: The joint family of Buddappa and Buddanna was governed by the Mitakshara School of Hindu law,

facts.text: No legislation in force in the territory by which on death of male member interest devolved upon widow; widow had only right to maintenance.

anchor.surface_text: and there was at the material time no legislation in force in the territory by which on the death of a male member in a joint Hindu family interest in the family estate devolved upon his widow. Such a widow had therefore only a right to receive maintenance from the estate.

facts.text: After Buddappa's death, the family consisted of sole surviving male coparcener Buddanna, his widowed mother and sisters.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the sole male surviving coparcener of the Hindu joint family, his widowed mother and sisters constitute a Hindu undivided family within the meaning of the Income-tax Act ?

facts.text: Previous year for assessment ended on November 8, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: in respect of the income of the previous year which ended on November 8, 1950

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that property continued to belong to HUF after Buddappa's death, represented by Buddanna.

anchor.surface_text: In the case in hand the property which yielded the income originally belonged to a Hindu undivided family. On the death of Buddappa the family which included a widow and females born in the family was represented by Buddanna alone but the property still continued to belong to that undivided family

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant said that there are certain intrinsic indications in the annual Finance Acts which support the contention that the income received or arising from property in the hands of a sole surviving male member in a joint Hindu family, even if there be females having a right to maintenance out of that property, is taxable as income of an individual, and not of the family. He relied by way of illustration upon the Finance Act, 1951, which in the First Schedule sets out the rates of income-tax payable by individuals, Hindu undivided family, unregistered firm and other association of persons.

arguments.claim: Under s.3, Hindu undivided family (not coparcenary) is assessable entity; joint family consists of lineal descendants including wives/unmarried daughters

anchor.surface_text: The first contention is plainly unsustainable. Under s. 3 of the Income-tax Act not a Hindu coparcenary but a Hindu undivided family is one of the assessable entities. A Hindu joint family consists of all persons lineally descended from a common ancestor, and includes their wives and unmarried daughters. A Hindu coparcenary is a much narrower body than the joint family it includes only those persons who acquire by birth an interest in the joint or coparcenary property,

arguments.claim: There may be joint Hindu family consisting of single male member and widows of deceased coparceners

anchor.surface_text: Therefore there may be a joint Hindu family consisting of a single male member and widows of deceased coparceners.

arguments.claim: Phrase 'Hindu undivided family' in statute refers to all schools of Hindu law, not just coparcenary; females can be members (Kalyanji Vithaldas)

anchor.surface_text: In Kalyanji Vithaldas Other v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bengal 5 I.T.R. 90 L.R. 64 I.A. 28 , delivering the judgment of the Judicial Committee, Sir George Rankin observed The phrase Hindu undivided family is used in the statute with reference not to one school only of Hindu law but to all schools and their Lordships think it a mistake in method to begin by pasting over the wider phrase of the Act the words Hindu coparcenary, all the more that it is not possible to say on the face of the Act that no female can be a member.

arguments.claim: Expression HUF in Income-tax Act used in sense of Hindu joint family under personal law; may consist of single male and widows

anchor.surface_text: The plea that there must be at least two male members to form a Hindu undivided family as a taxable entity also has no force. The expression Hindu undivided family in the Income-tax Act is used in the sense in which a Hindu joint family is understood under the personal law of Hindus. Under the Hindu system of law a joint family may consist of a single male member and widows of deceased male members, and apparently the Income-tax Act does not indicate that a Hindu undivided family as an assessable entity must consist of at least two male members.

arguments.claim: Finance Act proviso sets exemption limits but does not define HUF or require two partitionable members

anchor.surface_text: But the Schedule sets out the limits of exempted income it does not state or imply that a Hindu undivided family must consist of at least two members entitled to claim partition. The text of the clause furnishes a clear indication to the contrary.

arguments.claim: Return form requires member details only to apply Finance Act exemption limits

anchor.surface_text: but thereby it is not intended that a Hindu undivided family as an assessable entity does not exist so long as there are not at least two or more members entitled to claim partition. The information is required to be given in Part IIIA of the Form merely to enable the Income-tax Officer to consider which of the two parts of the proviso in the First Schedule to the relevant Finance Act prescribing the limit of exemption in respect of the Hindu undivided family applies.

arguments.claim: s.25A(1) purely procedural for post-partition assessment; does not imply multiple males required for HUF

anchor.surface_text: The sub-section only prescribes the procedure whereby the members of a family which has hitherto been assessed in the status of a Hindu undivided family may obtain an order that they may, because of partition of the joint status, be assessed as separated members. The clause is purely procedural it does not enact either expressly or by implication that a Hindu undivided family assessed as a unit must consist of at least two male members who are capable of demanding a partition.

arguments.claim: In Kalyanji, income was separate/ancestral but not HUF income; here property belonged to HUF and continues as such (distinction from Gomedalli upheld by JC)

anchor.surface_text: This distinction in the facts in the case then under discussion and the facts in Gomedalli Lakshminarayans case 3 I.T.R. 367. was not adverted to and the Board observed in Kalyanji Vithaldass case 5 I.T.R. 90 L.R. 64 I.A. 28. that the Bombay High Court arrived too readily at the conclusion that the income was the income of the family.

arguments.claim: Arunachalam case: single coparcener represents HUF; property remains joint family property with rights of females to maintenance

anchor.surface_text: A recent judgment of the Judicial Committee in a case arising from Ceylon Attorney-General of Ceylon v. A. R. Arunachalam Chettiar and Others L.R. 1957 A.C. 540 34 I.T.R. Suppl. 42. is in point. ... though it may be correct to speak of him the sole surviving coparcener as the owner, yet it is still correct to describe that which he owns as the joint family property.

arguments.claim: Property which yielded income belonged to HUF; after death of Buddappa, still belongs to undivided family represented by Buddanna; income taxable as HUF

anchor.surface_text: In the case in hand the property which yielded the income originally belonged to a Hindu undivided family. On the death of Buddappa the family which included a widow and females born in the family was represented by Buddanna alone but the property still continued to belong to that undivided family and income received therefrom was taxable as income of the Hindu undivided family.

holdings.text: Under s. 3 of the Income-tax Act not a Hindu coparcenary but a Hindu undivided family is one of the assessable entities

anchor.surface_text: The first contention is plainly unsustainable. Under s. 3 of the Income-tax Act not a Hindu coparcenary but a Hindu undivided family is one of the assessable entities. A Hindu joint family consists of all persons lineally descended from a common ancestor, and includes their wives and unmarried daughters.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.3 distinguishes HUF as broader than coparcenary; joint family includes lineal descendants, wives, daughters

holdings.text: There may be a joint Hindu family consisting of a single male member and widows of deceased coparceners

anchor.surface_text: the sons, grandsons and great-grandsons of the holder of the joint property for the time being. Therefore there may be a joint Hindu family consisting of a single male member and widows of deceased coparceners.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under Hindu personal law (Mitakshara), joint family narrower coparcenary; can persist with sole male and maintenance-entitled females

holdings.text: The expression Hindu undivided family in the Income-tax Act is used in the sense in which a Hindu joint family is understood under the personal law of Hindus and does not require at least two male members

anchor.surface_text: The plea that there must be at least two male members to form a Hindu undivided family as a taxable entity also has no force. The expression Hindu undivided family in the Income-tax Act is used in the sense in which a Hindu joint family is understood under the personal law of Hindus.

holdings.reasoning_summary: IT Act adopts personal law meaning of joint family; no statutory requirement for two males; females' maintenance rights suffice

holdings.text: The Schedule sets out the limits of exempted income it does not state or imply that a Hindu undivided family must consist of at least two members entitled to claim partition

anchor.surface_text: But the Schedule sets out the limits of exempted income it does not state or imply that a Hindu undivided family must consist of at least two members entitled to claim partition. The text of the clause furnishes a clear indication to the contrary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Finance Act proviso for exemption limits based on members, but textual reading shows no definition of HUF requiring partitionable members

holdings.text: Sub-section (1) of s. 25-A does not imply that a Hindu undivided family must consist of more male members than one

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section 1 of s. 25-A on which reliance was placed also does not imply that a Hindu undivided family must consist of more male members than one. The sub-section only prescribes the procedure whereby the members of a family

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.25A(1) is purely procedural for post-partition assessment; no implication on composition for ongoing HUF status

holdings.text: In the case in hand the property still continued to belong to that undivided family and income received therefrom was taxable as income of the Hindu undivided family

anchor.surface_text: In the case in hand the property which yielded the income originally belonged to a Hindu undivided family. On the death of Buddappa the family which included a widow and females born in the family was represented by Buddanna alone but the property still continued to belong to that undivided family and income received therefrom was taxable as income of the Hindu undivided family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying Hindu law and precedents (Arunachalam): HUF property does not cease on death of coparceners if represented by survivor with females' maintenance rights

holdings.text: The High Court was therefore right in recording their answers referred for opinion

anchor.surface_text: and income received therefrom was taxable as income of the Hindu undivided family. The High Court was therefore right in recording their answers referred for opinion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative reasoning upholds affirmative answers to all three referred questions on HUF status, assessment correctness, and AAC status correction

holdings.text: We express no opinion on the question whether a Hindu undivided family may for the purpose of the Indian Income-tax Act be treated as a taxable entity when it consists of a single member - male or female

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore right in recording their answers referred for opinion. We may observe that in this case we express no opinion on the question whether a Hindu undivided family may for the purpose of the Indian Income-tax Act be treated as a taxable entity when it consists of a single member - male or female.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue not arising on facts (females present); reserved

anchor.surface_text: Kalyanji Vithaldas Other v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bengal  5 I.T.R. 90 L.R. 64 I.A. 28 , delivering the judgment of the Judicial Committee, Sir George Rankin observed The phrase Hindu undivided family is used in the statute with reference number to one school only of Hindu law but to all schools and their Lordships think it a mistake in method to begin by pasting over the wider phrase of the Act the words Hindu companyarcenary, all the more that it is number possible to say on the face of the Act that numberfemale can be a member. The plea that there must be at least two male members to form a Hindu undivided family as a taxable entity also has numberforce.

precedents.case_name: Kalyanji Vithaldas v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Phrase 'Hindu undivided family' used in statute refers to all schools of Hindu law, not just coparcenary, and females can be members
precedents.cited_holding: The phrase Hindu undivided family is used in the statute with reference number to one school only of Hindu law but to all schools and their Lordships think it a mistake in method to begin by pasting over the wider phrase of the Act the words Hindu companyarcenary

precedents.citation: Kalyanji Vithaldass case  5 I.T.R. 90 L.R. 64 I.A. 28

anchor.surface_text: Kalyanji Vithaldass case  5 I.T.R. 90 L.R. 64 I.A. 28.  in which they disapproved of the view expressed by the Bombay High Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Gomedalli Laksminarayan  3 I.T.R. 123. . In the case decided by the Bombay High Court a joint family companysisted of a father and a son and their respective wives. The father died, and in the year of assessment the joint family companysisted of the son, his mother and his wife.

precedents.case_name: Kalyanji Vithaldas v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Disapproved Bombay High Court view on HUF with sole male and females

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Gomedalli Laksminarayan  3 I.T.R. 123

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Gomedalli Laksminarayan  3 I.T.R. 123. . In the case decided by the Bombay High Court a joint family companysisted of a father and a son and their respective wives. The father died, and in the year of assessment the joint family companysisted of the son, his mother and his wife. In dealing with the question referred by the Commissioner of Income-tax whether the income received by the son should be regarded as his individual income or as the income of a Hindu undivided family for the purpose of assessment to super-tax under the Indian Income-tax Act, the Bombay High Court held that the expression Hindu undivided family as used in the Income-tax Act includes families companysisting of a sole surviving male member and female members entitled to maintenance, and the income of the assessee should therefore be treated as the income of a Hindu undivided family.

precedents.cited_proposition: Income of sole surviving male member with mother and wife is income of HUF

precedents.citation: In re Moolji Sicka Others  3 I.T.R. 123

anchor.surface_text: In re Moolji Sicka Others  3 I.T.R. 123.  the Judicial Committee observed The High Court  of Calcutta  approached the cases by companysidering first whether the assessees family was a Hindu undivided family, and in the end left unanswered the question whether the income under assessment was the income of that family. This is due numberdoubt to the way in which the Commissioner had stated the questions. But, after all if the relevant Hindu law had been that the income belonged, number to the assessee himself, but to the assessee, his wife and daughter jointly, it is difficult to see how that association of individuals companyld have been refused the description Hindu joint family.

precedents.cited_proposition: Approach of Calcutta High Court in Kalyanji appeals

anchor.surface_text: Gomedalli Lakshminarayans case  3 I.T.R. 367.  the property was ancestral in the hands of the father, and the son had acquired by birth an interest therein. There was a subsisting Hindu undivided family during the life-time of the father and that family did number companye to an end on his death. On these facts the High Court of Bombay held that the income received from the property was liable to super-tax in the hands of the son who was the surviving made member of the Hindu undivided family in the year of assessment.

precedents.cited_proposition: Property ancestral, HUF continues after father's death with sole son

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. A. P. Swamy Gomedalli  5 I.T.R. 416

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax v. A. P. Swamy Gomedalli  5 I.T.R. 416. . It may however be recalled that in Kalyanji Vithaldass case  5 I.T.R. 90 L.R. 64 I.A. 28.  income assessed to tax belonged separately to four out of six partners of the remaining two it was from an ancestral source but the fact that each such partner had a wife or daughter did number make that income from an ancestral source income of the undivided family of the partner, his wife and daughter.

precedents.case_name: CIT v. A. P. Swamy Gomedalli
precedents.cited_proposition: Income of sole surviving coparcener taxed as individual for super-tax

precedents.citation: Attorney-General of Ceylon v. A. R. Arunachalam Chettiar and Others  L.R.  1957  A.C. 540 34 I.T.R. Suppl. 42

anchor.surface_text: Attorney-General of Ceylon v. A. R. Arunachalam Chettiar and Others  L.R.  1957  A.C. 540 34 I.T.R. Suppl. 42.  is in point. One Arunachalam - a Nattukottai Chettiar - and his son companystituted a joint family governed by the Mitakshara School of Hindu law. The father and the son were domiciled in India and had trading and other interests in India, Ceylon and Far Eastern Countries  Vide Attorney-General v. A. R. Arunachalam Chettiar  No. 1  -  L.R.  1957  A.C. 513 .

precedents.case_name: Attorney-General of Ceylon v. A. R. Arunachalam Chettiar
precedents.cited_proposition: Sole surviving coparcener still part of HUF, property remains joint family property
precedents.cited_holding: Arunachalam was at his death a member of a Hindu undivided family... property has been and has number ceased to be joint family property

precedents.citation: Attorney-General v. A. R. Arunachalam Chettiar  No. 1  -  L.R.  1957  A.C. 513

anchor.surface_text: Vide Attorney-General v. A. R. Arunachalam Chettiar  No. 1  -  L.R.  1957  A.C. 513 . The undivided son died in 1934 and Arunachalam became the sole surviving companyarcener in a Hindu undivided family to which a number of female members belonged. Arunachalam died in 1938 shortly after the Estate Duty Ordinance No. 1 of 1938 came into operation in Ceylon.

precedents.case_name: Attorney-General v. A. R. Arunachalam Chettiar No. 1
precedents.cited_proposition: Background facts on Arunachalam family business

anchor.surface_text: The first contention is plainly unsustainable. Under s. 3 of the Income-tax Act not a Hindu coparcenary but a Hindu undivided family is one of the assessable entities. A Hindu joint family consists of all persons lineally descended from a common ancestor, and includes their wives and unmarried daughters.
The High Court was therefore right in recording their answers referred for opinion.

anchor.surface_text: The plea that there must be at least two male members to form a Hindu undivided family as a taxable entity also has no force. The expression Hindu undivided family in the Income-tax Act is used in the sense in which a Hindu joint family is understood under the personal law of Hindus.
The High Court was therefore right in recording their answers referred for opinion.

anchor.surface_text: In the case in hand the property which yielded the income originally belonged to a Hindu undivided family. On the death of Buddappa the family which included a widow and females born in the family was represented by Buddanna alone but the property still continued to belong to that undivided family and income received therefrom was taxable as income of the Hindu undivided family.
